intro: Cymbaria mongolica, commonly known as the Mongolian bellflower, is a perennial herb native to the grasslands of Mongolia and northern China. It belongs to the Campanulaceae family and is characterized by its bell-shaped, blue to purple flowers that bloom in late summer. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 centimeters and has lance-shaped leaves with a rough texture. It thrives in well-drained soils and full sun, making it a hardy species adapted to arid and semi-arid climates. Cymbaria mongolica is often used in traditional medicine for its purported health benefits.
